mustsees.desc: Bali celebrates its own Independence Day on August 17th with a colorful parade. Best spot to see the parade is its Northern capital Singaraja - it’s a couple of hours long, very cheerful event and since Singaraja is not the most touristy town you’re likely to be celebrating it like a local.
mustsees.title: Bali Independence Day parade in Singaraja

badges.desc: While $10-$20 accommodation in the largest towns in still possible to find, booking is advised, otherwise on arrival you might have to walk around for a while in order to find a suitable place to stay. Accommodation and transportation costs generally grow about 30% in high season.

South of Bali will be really crowded, especially around Kuta. This is the time when the risk of getting scammed is at its peak. Beware of overly friendly locals who offer you “a great holiday deal” - timeshare scam is popular. Money exchange is another concern - do it in certified places only - you can count your changed money several times, but you’re still likely to walk out with at least 10% of it missing (the trick is a very special cashier table with a crack in it)

This is the time when water around the South is very clear - perfect for snorkeling and diving. Get out of the mainland and visit one of the smallest islands South of Kuta (e.g. Lembongan) or islands around Lombok and you will enjoy the best of what the underwater world can offer. In comparison to many advertised snorkeling spots in Thailand, the reef around Bali is still very alive.
